title: 110_hr2109
content: The "Empowering Our Local Communities Act of 2007" includes provisions for certain killings by illegal aliens, imposing fines and imprisonment for manslaughter while under the influence of alcohol and operating a motor vehicle. It also addresses improper entry by or presence of aliens in the United States. SEC. 3 of the "Empowering Our Local Communities Act of 2007" addresses improper entry or presence of aliens in the US, amending Section 275 of the Immigration and Nationality Act. SEC. 4 focuses on the Institutional Removal Program (IRP). The Department of Homeland Security will continue and expand the Institutional Removal Program (IRP) to identify and remove removable criminal aliens from Federal and State correctional facilities, ensuring they are not released into the community. All States receiving Federal funds for incarcerating criminal aliens must cooperate with the IRP to expedite the removal process. The Department of Homeland Security will expand the Institutional Removal Program (IRP) to identify and remove criminal aliens from correctional facilities. States must cooperate with the IRP to promptly transfer removable aliens to Federal custody after completing their prison sentences. Law enforcement officers have the authority to detain illegal aliens for up to 14 days post-sentence or issue detainers for further detention. The Institutional Removal Program (IRP) aims to transfer criminal aliens from state prisons to Federal custody after their sentences. Technology like video conferencing and mobile access to databases will be utilized for this program. Appropriations of $100 million for 2008, $115 million for 2009, and $130 million for 2010 are authorized. The Institutional Removal Program (IRP) aims to transfer criminal aliens from state prisons to Federal custody after their sentences. Appropriations for the program are $130 million for fiscal year 2010, $145 million for fiscal year 2011, and $160 million for fiscal year 2012. SEC. 5. TRAINING OF STATE AND LOCAL PERSONNEL PERFORMING IMMIGRATION FUNCTIONS. Authorization of Appropriations for reimbursement of State or political subdivision expenses related to immigration functions. $40,000,000 authorized for fiscal year 2008, remaining available until September 30, 2009. Eligible recipients must have a written agreement under section 287(g) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. Employees of the State or subdivision may be authorized to perform immigration officer functions and receive training from the Department of Homeland Security. Expenses incurred for this training include travel, transportation, and subsistence costs. Expenses covered for immigration officer training include travel, lodging, meals, per diem allowance, and costs for temporary replacements. Nothing in the Act or any law should require immigration-related training for State or local law enforcement officers. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a report to Congress within 18 months of the Act's enactment, evaluating the effectiveness of the program under section 287(g) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. The report should include the participation of States and political subdivisions in the program. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a report to Congress evaluating the effectiveness of the program under section 287(g) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. The report should include discussions with States, data on apprehensions of unlawfully present aliens, hardships faced by participants, and steps taken to encourage participation.
